description: Borrowed from German Graphit (A. G. Werner 1789), from Ancient Greek γράφω (gráphō, “I write”).

entries.meaning: An allotrope of carbon, consisting of planes of carbon atoms arranged in hexagonal arrays with the planes stacked loosely, that is used as a dry lubricant, in "lead" pencils, and as a moderator in some nuclear reactors.
Short for graphite-reinforced plastic, a composite plastic made with graphite fibers noted for light weight strength and stiffness.
examples: Modern tennis racquets are made of graphite, fibreglass and other man-made materials.

entries.meaning: A grey colour, resembling graphite or the marks made with a graphite pencil.

verbs.description: graphite (third-person singular simple present graphites, present participle graphiting, simple past and past participle graphited)
